title: What if intelligent life is just not that big of a deal? - Quora

response.answer_text: I take this to mean that it’s possible that intelligent life might be far more common than we think. If so, I can only echo Enrico Fermi’s “Where is everyone?”. Given the complex hydrocarbons in space, it wouldn’t be too surprising if simple life were not reasonably frequent, under favourable conditions. But intelligence additionally needs stability for a long, long time. That increases the odds against considerably. Of course, it’s quite possible they are here already, but are so far ahead of us we can’t detect them.
I suspect that LIFE is a big deal, intelligent life is a ‘fringe benefit’ as we probably be too far away to realistically ever meet.
